Intro.0: A new iOS malware that exploits Apple DRM flaws has been discovered—and it's one that could potentially affect “any device,” even non-jailbroken ones.
Intro.1: The most common cybercrime scenarios that users need to be wary of, and how to avoid them.
Intro.2: A new iOS malware that exploits Apple DRM flaws has been discovered—and it's one that could potentially affect “any device,” even non-jailbroken ones.
Intro.3: The most common cybercrime scenarios that users need to be wary of, and how to avoid them.
Intro.4: Cybercriminals used PoSeidon PoS malware to steal payment card and biometric data from Avanti kiosks  [Read More]
Intro.5: A new iOS malware family dubbed AceDeceiver leverages design flaws in Apple’s FairPlay DRM technology to infect devices  [Read More]
Intro.6: Researchers from Proofpoint say they recently discovered a rogue app store that lets iOS device users download apps from a catalog offering more than 1 million apps, without having to jailbreak their device.  [Read More]
Intro.7: The number of Mac OS X systems infected with malware during the first nine months of 2015 is seven times higher than in all of 2014, Symantec reports.  [Read More]
Intro.8: XcodeGhost compiler malware updated with iOS 9 support. Infections spotted in US enterprises, FireEye warns.  [Read More]
Intro.9: KeyRaider iOS malware used to steal credentials for 225,000 Apple accounts. Stolen data used for malicious jailbreak tweaks.  [Read More]
Intro.10: iOS spyware used by the Pawn Storm cyber espionage group to steal valuable information from targets.  [Read More]
Intro.11: According to a report from Arxan Technologies, hacked versions of 97% of the top 100 paid Android apps and 87% of the top 100 paid Apple iOS apps appear in unofficial app stores and app distribution sites.  [Read More]
Intro.12: Researchers at Palo Alto Networks identified a piece of malware called WireLurker that was designed to target Mac OS X and iOS users. Experts believe WireLurker once again shows that Apple devices are not immune to malware.  [Read More]
Intro.13: Researchers at Palo Alto Networks have uncovered a new piece of malware designed to target devices running Apple's OS X and iOS operating systems and might have been installed by hundreds of thousands of users.  [Read More]
Intro.14: Security researchers have uncovered two pieces of mobile malware appearing to be used by the Chinese government to keep a close eye on pro-democracy protesters.  [Read More]
Intro.15: Kaspersky Lab researchers are saying they have discovered an iOS app that they are outright calling malware based upon the fact that it grabs a users phonebook details (without first notifying the user) and sends spam SMS messages.  [Read More]
Intro.16: After MyBios (Mebromi) became the first malware to successfully infect the Award BIOS and survive a reboot to own the system, BIOS-based rootkits became the toast of the malware research community  [Read More]
